metadata.subject: The Greatest Dirty Joke Ever Told

relationships.description: Used political clout to influence history curriculum

analysis.purpose: Cultural critique of censorship trends and defense of free expression in comedy and entertainment
analysis.significance: Documents cultural climate post-9/11 and growing censorship efforts, connecting comedy to broader political and cultural freedom issues

notable_quotes: "I think we have the same power to deal with cable as over the air" - Ted Stevens on expanding censorship to cable/satellite TV
"Even as we're constantly told we're in a war for 'freedom' abroad, freedom in our culture at home has been under attack ever since" - Frank Rich's concluding statement
"It's a dangerous world we're living in when you get to the point that a joke about Jude Law is the most controversial thing in the Oscar show" - Bob Saget

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this cultural commentary article

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed - this is a cultural commentary article about censorship and free speech

details: References to Comedy Central cutting content
MTV and Howard Stern being targeted

public_knowledge.context: New York Times opinion piece discussing public cultural and political issues around censorship post-9/11

analysis.summary: This New York Times opinion piece by Frank Rich analyzes the cultural climate of censorship post-9/11, using Gilbert Gottfried's controversial Aristocrats joke performance as a starting point to discuss growing government restrictions on entertainment, cable television, and cultural expression, while connecting these trends to broader political influences on education and historical narratives.
